posts.title: Welcome to My Retro Blog
posts.excerpt: Check out my new blog section with a classic early 2000s vibe. It's simple, it's clean, and it just works.
posts.content:
Hey there! Welcome to my retro blog section. If you're reading this, you've stumbled upon my attempt to bring back the glory days of the early 2000s web.

No fancy frameworks, no complex build processes - just good old HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. The way the web was meant to be.

I built this blog section to share my thoughts on software development, machine learning, and whatever else comes to mind. Expect posts about backend systems, AI, and maybe some nostalgic rants about how things used to be simpler.

Stay tuned for more content!

posts.title: Why I Still Love Backend Development
posts.excerpt: Backend development is where the real magic happens. Let me tell you why I'm still passionate about building systems behind the scenes.
posts.content:
There's something incredibly satisfying about building robust backend systems. While frontend gets all the glory with its flashy animations and beautiful designs, the backend is where the real complexity lives.

I've spent years working with microservices, gRPC, event-driven architectures, and distributed systems. Each project teaches me something new about scalability, reliability, and performance.

At Pariti, I got to work on systems serving over 100,000 users. The challenges of maintaining uptime, optimizing database queries, and handling peak loads - that's what gets me excited.

Some of my favorite technologies: PostgreSQL for its reliability, Kafka for event streaming, and Kubernetes for orchestration. These tools have been battle-tested and they just work.

If you're just starting out in backend development, my advice is simple: learn the fundamentals first. Understand databases, networking, and system design. The frameworks will come and go, but the fundamentals remain constant.

posts.title: Machine Learning in Production: Lessons Learned
posts.excerpt: Deploying ML models to production is different from training them in notebooks. Here are some hard-earned lessons from the trenches.
posts.content:
Everyone talks about training machine learning models, but deploying them to production? That's where things get interesting.

I've integrated LLMs using OpenAI and Hugging Face, built vector search systems with Qdrant, and optimized model inference pipelines. Here's what I've learned:

Lesson 1: Model Versioning is Critical

You need to version your models just like you version your code. When something breaks at 3 AM, you need to know exactly which model version is running in production.

Lesson 2: Monitor Everything

Don't just monitor your servers - monitor your model predictions, inference times, and data drift. Your model might be running fine but producing garbage predictions.

Lesson 3: Optimize for Latency

In production, users don't care about your F1 score. They care about getting results fast. Sometimes a simpler, faster model is better than a complex, accurate one.

Machine learning engineering is still software engineering. All the best practices apply: testing, CI/CD, monitoring, and documentation.

posts.title: The Beauty of Simple Solutions
posts.excerpt: Not every problem needs a complex solution. Sometimes the simplest approach is the best approach.
posts.content:
I've noticed a trend in software development: we love to over-engineer things. We reach for complex frameworks, intricate architectures, and elaborate patterns when a simple solution would work just fine.

This website is a perfect example. It's just static HTML, CSS, and vanilla JavaScript. No build process, no dependency hell, no framework fatigue. And you know what? It works perfectly.

I've built production systems serving thousands of users with simple, straightforward architectures. Not every project needs microservices. Not every app needs Redux. Not every website needs React.

When to Keep It Simple

  • Your project is small and likely to stay small
  • You have limited time or resources
  • Performance and load time are critical
  • You want to minimize maintenance burden

The next time you start a project, ask yourself: what's the simplest thing that could possibly work? Start there. You can always add complexity later if you actually need it.

Remember: simple doesn't mean simplistic. It means elegant, maintainable, and focused on solving the problem at hand.
